responses: Hello! How can I assist you with your health concerns today?
Goodbye! Take care and consult a doctor if needed.
I was developed by Yasmine Berred (yb) as a medical assistant bot.
I analyze symptoms and suggest possible conditions. Always consult a doctor for proper diagnosis.

patterns: nasal congestion itchy watery eyes sneezing runny nose sore throat
nasal congestion itchy watery eyes sneezing
responses: You may have an allergy. Try to avoid what causes the symptoms and see a doctor if it gets worse.
You are showing symptoms of anemia, possibly due to iron deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency, or other causes. Consult a doctor for proper diagnosis.

patterns: loss of smell swollen lymph nodes
responses: You are showing symptoms of a **cold** or **flu**. Rest, hydrate, and consider over-the-counter relief. If fever is high (>38.5°C/101°F) or breathing difficulties occur, seek medical help.
You are showing symptoms of asthma. Avoid triggers (dust, pollen, smoke), use prescribed inhalers if available, and seek medical attention if symptoms worsen or breathing becomes severely difficult.
You are showing common early signs of pregnancy. Consider taking a home pregnancy test. For confirmation, schedule an appointment with a healthcare provider to begin prenatal care if positive.

You are showing classic symptoms of hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid). This requires medical evaluation with blood tests (TSH, T3/T4). Untreated hyperthyroidism can lead to serious complications like heart problems or thyroid storm. Please consult a doctor promptly.

You are showing classic symptoms of hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid). This requires blood tests (TSH, T4) for diagnosis. Hypothyroidism is easily treatable with thyroid hormone replacement. Please see a doctor for evaluation.

You are showing classic symptoms of diabetes. This requires urgent medical evaluation with blood glucose testing (fasting sugar or HbA1c). Untreated diabetes can lead to dangerous complications. Please see a doctor within 24-48 hours.

You are showing potentially dangerous symptoms of severe hypertension (high blood pressure). This requires IMMEDIATE medical attention as it may indicate hypertensive crisis (>180/120 mmHg) which can lead to stroke or organ damage. Call emergency services if experiencing chest pain/severe headache.

You are showing symptoms that may indicate acute HIV infection (especially if recent exposure within 2-6 weeks). URGENT testing is required - modern HIV treatments can prevent progression to AIDS if started early. Seek immediate medical care for PEP (post-exposure prophylaxis) if exposure occurred <72 hours ago.

You're experiencing symptoms of a panic attack. While frightening, these episodes are not life-threatening. Try slow breathing (4-7-8 technique: inhale 4s, hold 7s, exhale 8s) and grounding exercises (name 5 things you see). Seek medical evaluation to rule out cardiac causes, especially if first episode.

You are showing concerning symptoms of possible bone pathology. These symptoms REQUIRE urgent orthopedic evaluation with imaging (X-ray/MRI) and possibly biopsy. While most bone lesions are benign, early detection of malignant tumors significantly improves outcomes.

You are showing classic symptoms of malaria. This is a MEDICAL EMERGENCY if you've been in a malaria-endemic area recently. Immediate testing (blood smear/RDT) and treatment are required - severe malaria can be fatal within 24 hours. Seek care NOW if you have any fever after tropical travel.

You are showing symptoms of dengue fever. This requires URGENT medical attention if you've been in a dengue-endemic area. Watch for warning signs of severe dengue (hemorrhagic fever) - these appear 3-7 days after first symptoms and REQUIRE IMMEDIATE HOSPITALIZATION. Hydrate frequently and avoid NSAIDs (use paracetamol only).

You are showing classic symptoms of Hepatitis B infection. This requires URGENT medical evaluation with blood tests (HBsAg, liver function tests). Acute HBV can become chronic if untreated, leading to cirrhosis/liver cancer. Practice strict precautions to prevent transmission (blood/body fluids). Vaccination is available for contacts.

You're showing symptoms of paronychia (nail fold infection). For acute cases: Soak in warm water 3-4x daily, avoid nail biting. If pus present or symptoms persist >48 hours, seek medical care for possible drainage/antibiotics. Chronic cases require identifying/treating underlying causes (eczema, diabetes).

You are showing concerning symptoms that may indicate pancreatic cancer. These require URGENT medical evaluation with imaging (CT/MRI) and tumor marker tests (CA19-9). Early detection significantly improves outcomes. Seek immediate attention if jaundice or persistent pain develops, especially with weight loss.

You're showing classic symptoms of chickenpox (varicella). ISOLATE immediately - highly contagious until all blisters crust. Use calamine lotion/cool baths for itching. Avoid scratching to prevent scarring. Seek URGENT care if: high fever >39°C, breathing difficulty, rash near eyes, or confusion develops.

This baby is showing symptoms of significant neonatal jaundice that may indicate dangerous bilirubin levels. This is a MEDICAL EMERGENCY - untreated high bilirubin can cause permanent brain damage (kernicterus). Seek IMMEDIATE pediatric evaluation with bilirubin testing. Breastfeed frequently (10-12x/day) to help excretion.

You're experiencing acute diarrhea. Priority is rehydration - drink oral rehydration solutions (ORS) frequently. Eat bland foods (BRAT diet: Bananas, Rice, Applesauce, Toast). Seek medical care if: dehydration signs appear, symptoms persist >2 days, or if you see blood in stool. Avoid anti-diarrheals initially in infectious cases.

You're showing symptoms of dyspepsia (indigestion). Try eating smaller meals, avoiding triggers (fatty/spicy foods, caffeine), and elevating your head at night. If symptoms persist >2 weeks or you develop alarm features (weight loss, vomiting blood), seek medical evaluation to rule out ulcers or other conditions.

You're showing symptoms of constipation. Increase fiber intake (25-30g/day), drink more water, and exercise regularly. Seek medical care if: symptoms persist >3 weeks, you see blood in stool, or experience unexplained weight loss.
You're showing RED FLAG symptoms of appendicitis. This is a SURGICAL EMERGENCY - go to ER immediately. Do not eat/drink or take painkillers until evaluated.
You're showing symptoms of generalized anxiety disorder. Consider relaxation techniques and CBT. Seek professional help if: symptoms persist >6 months and impair daily functioning.
You're showing concerning symptoms of Crohn's disease. This requires gastroenterology evaluation with colonoscopy and imaging. Untreated IBD increases cancer risk.
You're showing hallmark symptoms of narcolepsy. This requires sleep study (polysomnography + MSLT) for diagnosis. Stimulants and scheduled naps help manage symptoms.
You're showing symptoms of cystinuria (inherited stone disorder). Increase fluid intake (>3L/day), alkalinize urine, and see urology for 24h urine testing and thiol drugs.
You're showing prostatitis symptoms. Acute bacterial cases need prompt antibiotics. Chronic cases may require alpha-blockers, anti-inflammatories, and pelvic floor therapy.
You're showing classic angina symptoms suggesting coronary artery disease. STOP ACTIVITY. Use nitroglycerin if prescribed. Call EMS if pain persists >15 minutes (possible MI).
You're showing possible West Nile symptoms. Seek IMMEDIATE care for neurological signs (confusion, weakness). No specific treatment - supportive care only. Prevent mosquito bites.
EMERGENCY: This may indicate invasive staph infection or sepsis. Seek IMMEDIATE medical care. Do not delay treatment.
Schedule urgent ophthalmology evaluation. Use Amsler grid for self-monitoring. AREDS supplements may help dry AMD.
RETINAL EMERGENCY - requires evaluation within 24 hours to prevent permanent vision loss. Do not wait.
Acute angle-closure is MEDICAL EMERGENCY. Chronic glaucoma requires regular IOP monitoring and lifelong treatment.
Consult gynecology for pelvic exam and ultrasound. Hysterectomy is one of several treatment options available.
OTC antifungals (clotrimazole) often effective. Seek care if: recurrent (>4x/year), pregnant, or immunocompromised.
EMERGENT: This life-threatening disorder requires multidisciplinary care (psychiatry + nutrition + medicine).
Requires spirometry for diagnosis. Smoking cessation critical. Vaccinate against flu/pneumonia. Use inhalers as prescribed.
Pulmonary rehab improves outcomes. Oxygen if hypoxemic. Surgical options (LVRS) in select cases.
Apply warm compresses 3-4x/day. Do NOT squeeze. Seek care if: fever develops, size >5cm, or facial location.
Early intervention with silicone sheets/injections improves outcomes. Surgical excision often recurs without adjuvant therapy.
You're showing classic rosacea symptoms. Avoid triggers (alcohol, spicy foods). Use gentle skincare and consult a dermatologist for prescription treatments.
URGENT: Shingles requires antiviral medication within 72 hours of rash appearance. Seek immediate medical care to prevent complications.
Use medicated anti-dandruff shampoos (containing zinc pyrithione or ketoconazole). See a doctor if redness/spreading occurs.
Clean skin gently twice daily. Avoid picking. Over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide helps. Severe cases need dermatology care.
Most warts resolve in 2 years. Salicylic acid treatments help. Freezing (cryotherapy) by a doctor is faster.
This autoimmune condition requires rheumatology evaluation. Early treatment prevents organ damage.
Topical corticosteroids often help. Oral lesions need monitoring for cancer risk.
Schedule a cognitive evaluation. Early diagnosis of Alzheimer's/dementia allows better management.
Antihistamines provide relief. Seek emergency care if throat swelling or breathing difficulty occurs.
This life-threatening eating disorder requires psychiatric + nutritional care. Confidential help is available.
